DIV.DIV: This article is about the game engine. For the user interface, see Unity (user interface) Unity (disambiguation)

TD.DIV: The current logo used for Unity

DIV.P:
Unity gives users the ability to create games in both 2D 3D C# drag and drop Boo
[7]
JavaScript UnityScript
[8]
The engine has support for the following graphics APIs Direct3D OpenGL OpenGL ES WebGL video game consoles Metal Vulkan Direct3D 12

Within 2D games, Unity allows importation of sprites and an advanced 2D world renderer. For 3D games, Unity allows specification of texture compression mipmaps
[5]
bump mapping reflection mapping parallax mapping screen space ambient occlusion shadow maps render-to-texture
[9]

Since about 2016 Unity also offers cloud-based services to developers, these are presently: Unity Ads, Unity Analytics, Unity Certification, Unity Cloud Build, Unity Everyplay, Unity IAP ("In app purchase" - for the Apple and Google app stores), Unity Multiplayer, Unity Performance Reporting, Unity Collaborate and Unity Hub.
Unity supports the creation of custom vertexes, fragments (or pixels), tessellation, compute shaders Cg High-Level Shading Language Nvidia

The Unity editor is supported on Windows macOS Linux
[10]
iOS Android Tizen Windows Universal Windows Platform macOS Linux WebGL PlayStation 4 PlayStation Vita Xbox One Wii U 3DS Oculus Rift Google Cardboard SteamVR PlayStation VR Gear VR Windows Mixed Reality Daydream Android TV Samsung Smart TV tvOS Nintendo Switch Fire OS ARCore Vuforia

Unity formerly supported seven other platforms including its own Unity Web Player. The Unity Web Player was a browser plugin that was only supported on Windows and macOS via Chrome Internet Explorer 11 Firefox
[11]
WebGL
[12]
C# C++ JavaScript
[13]
[14]

Unity is the default software development kit Wii U video game console
[15]
[16]

During its first ten years as a product the paid versions of Unity were sold outright; in 2016 the corporation changed to a subscription model.
[17]
Unity has one free and three paid licensing options:

TABLE.style: text-align: center; font-size: 100%; width: auto; table-layout: fixed;

TR.TD: Made With Unity and optional Custom Animation
Custom Animation and/or Made with Unity

$420 billed $35 per month for a mandatory 12 months.
[18]
Custom Animation and/or Made with Unity

$1,500 billed at $125 per month for a mandatory 12 months.
[19]
Custom Animation and/or Made with Unity

TD.DIV:
This section needs expansion You can help by adding to it
( June 2018

DIV.P: The first version of Unity (1.0.0) was created by colleagues: David Helgason, Joachim Ante and Nicholas Francis in Denmark. The initial product launched on June 6, 2005. The goal was to create an affordable game engine with professional tools for amateur game developers while “democratizing the game development” industry. The three were inspired by the easy workflow, simple asset pipeline, and drag-and-drop interface of Apple’s Final Cut Pro product. When originally released, Unity was available solely for Mac OS X, and developers could only deploy their creations to a few platforms. The current version (4.3.1 as of this writing) is supported on both Windows and Mac OS X, and offers at least a dozen target platforms.

In 2012, VentureBeat said, "Few companies have contributed as much to the flowing of independently produced games as Unity Technologies. ... More than 1.3 million developers are using its tools to create gee-whiz graphics in their iOS, Android, console, PC, and web-based games. ... Unity wants to be the engine for multi-platform games, period."
[15]

For the Apple Design Awards at the 2006 WWDC Apple, Inc.
[20]
[21]
Game Developer
[22]
Develop
[23]

Unity 5 was launched on March 3, 2015.
[24]
The Verge
[25]

Following the release of Unity 5, Unity Technologies drew some criticism for the high volume of quickly produced games published on the Steam distribution platform by inexperienced developers.
[26]
John Riccitiello
[27]

In December 2016, Unity Technologies announced that they will change the versioning numbering system sequence-based identifiers year of release
[28]
